At 16:00 you can observe another phenomenon - the influence of solvent viscosity on the fluorescence quantum yield of this dye! There is a non-radiative decay channel that involves rotation about the double bond when this molecule is in the excited state. In the more viscous solvent (DMSO), it is more difficult for this rotation to occur, so more of the absorbed photons are re-emitted.

Kulinich, Andrii V., Vladimir V. Kurdyukov, and Alexander A. Ishchenko. "Effect of bulky substituents in the donor and acceptor terminal groups on solvatochromism of Brooker's merocyanine." New Journal of Chemistry 43.19 (2019): 7379-7385.

Or just make your own piperidine !!!
I started from delta-hidroxyvaleric acid.
Heating the ammonium salt of the acid affords delta-valerolactam.
Alternatively, you can heat delta-aminovaleric acid it will easily lose water and turn into a lactam.
You can heat them in a dry solvent with desiccants or you can boil the water off... it doesn’t matter really.
Then you can reduce the valerolactam to piperidine via a dry Clemmensen reduction (zinc dust + HCl in diethyl ether solution) or by treating it with LiAlH4 in diethyl ether.
If you choose the Clemmensen method you should use excess HCl because you will end up with piperidinium chloride.

Had to Google because I was curious, piperidine is a controlled substance due to being considered an immediate precursor to the extremely powerful opioid fentanyl. The little bit I remember from my pharmacy training is that a person who does not already have a high tolerance to opioids can have really bad reactions to fentanyl. Thus the problem with it being integrated in the illicit drug market and why piperidine is controlled.

@NileRed Re the use of piperidine (at 10:45). Why not use 4-methylpiperidine? Piperidine is restricted in academic labs as it's a precursor for PCP, so to circumvent this we usually buy 4-methylpiperide which isn't regulated (as it can't be used for PCP synthesis; the 4-methyl analog is far less potent) but the reactivity of the cyclic secondary base in nearly identical. Pyrrolidine also works as a cyclic secondary base.

Congrats man! I can assure you that second stage crop (red crystals) was actually dye in it's protonated form as hydroiodide salt. Not the alcohol with -OH, which i bet should be colorless, but final product with double bound. Final step with KOH is no more than deprotonation of betaine/quinone ylidene salt thus formed. This may be an issue lowering yield, as some intermediate alcohol can still remains in solution and been filtered off. Another strong issue I 100% agree with you is triethylamine catalyst which is not even close to piperidine and pyrrolidine in terms of basicity and catalytic reactivity. On the other hand the prolonged reflux can destroy final product or especially alcohol intermediate -reaction time is always tradeoff between conversion of SM and tar formation

I guess I'll address the elephant in the room. You describe solvatochromism as a switching between tautomers with the actual percentage depending on the solvent environment. That isn't what happens. It's just two resonance forms where the relative character of each is dependent on the solvent environment. Now, that probably sounds pedantic, which it is, but the tautomer thing is one of the most common misconceptions with resonance, and the fact that this is how resonance works completely refuses your crystal explanation. I don't know exactly what's happening with the crystal, though I honestly don't see anything that I wouldn't just chalk up to Beer's law, but it's definitely not because it crystallized as the two different tautomers.

you described it as an equilibrium, but the imagery shown with the "A and B" form of MOED appears to be the notation for resonance structures! this might be a minor nitpick, but there is a difference. in the case of resonance, "A and B" aren't two separate forms of the molecule constantly being swapped between, or existing in equilibrium. the two apparent molecules are not actually separate, but a skeletal structure can't show them accurately, so there's just a double headed arrow pointing between the two forms.

each molecule is BOTH of those structures at once, and there's ways you can tell which resonance structure affects the overall molecule more or less. in this particular case, that means different solvents affect the weight one of the structures has over the other in its overall molecular form, and then that in turn changes the color!

(disclaimer, i'm just now taking college organic chem, this may still be inaccurate to some degree?)

One point that could improve the otherwise high standard: recrystallisation in a beaker is considered poor practice; this is because of the loss of solvent during boiling, especially with volatile solvents like ethanol. It’s a greater issue when using mixed solvents, as the lower boiling solvent will be lost preferentially. The preferred technique is to use a flask, with reflux condenser for volatile solvents.
I remember, as an undergraduate, watching this point being driven home to a fellow student, who was attempting to recrystallise in a beaker, which was forbidden: the lecturer came up and emptied his (tobacco) pipe ash into the beaker, saying to the dismayed student “well, you’d better start again then!” Such lessons, generally, are not forgotten!

Awesome video, NR! Strictly speaking, the two structures of MOED are resonance forms, not distinct equilibrating minima. Polar solvents cause a polarization of the electron density that makes the charged resonance form more representative of the true structure than the neutral form. As this occurs, the energy gap between the ground and excited states shrinks, causing a shift in color toward red.
